two_pointer_techniques.name: Converging Pointers (Opposite Ends)
two_pointer_techniques.movement: Pointers start at indices 0 and n-1 and move toward each other.
two_pointer_techniques.key_insight: Commonly used on sorted data to prune the search space from both ends simultaneously based on a comparison.

two_pointer_techniques.name: Slow-Fast Pointers (Tortoise and Hare)
two_pointer_techniques.movement: Both pointers move in the same direction, but one moves at double the speed of the other.
two_pointer_techniques.key_insight: Ideal for detecting cycles in a structure or finding structural midpoints in a single pass.
common_applications: Finding the Middle of a Linked List

two_pointer_techniques.name: Sliding Window (Fixed or Variable)
two_pointer_techniques.movement: Both pointers move in the same direction; the leading pointer expands the window while the trailing pointer shrinks it.
two_pointer_techniques.key_insight: Converts nested loops into a single pass to find a subarray or substring meeting specific criteria.
common_applications: Maximum Sum Subarray of Size K

two_pointer_techniques.name: Diverging Pointers (Expand from Center)
two_pointer_techniques.movement: Pointers start at the same (or adjacent) center index and move outward toward the boundaries.
two_pointer_techniques.key_insight: The most efficient way to check for symmetry or palindromic properties starting from the inside out.

two_pointer_techniques.name: Multi-Structure Pointers (Independent)
two_pointer_techniques.movement: One pointer is assigned to each of two different arrays/lists; they move independently based on logic.
two_pointer_techniques.key_insight: Used to synchronize, merge, or compare two separate datasets efficiently.
common_applications: K-th Smallest Element in Two Sorted Arrays

two_pointer_techniques.name: Read-Write Pointers (In-place)
two_pointer_techniques.movement: Both move in the same direction; the 'Read' pointer scans all elements while the 'Write' pointer only moves when data is modified.
two_pointer_techniques.key_insight: Enables in-place data transformation with O(1) space by overwriting existing memory.

two_pointer_techniques.name: Saddleback Search (2D Pointers)
two_pointer_techniques.movement: Pointers start at a corner of a 2D matrix (e.g., Top-Right) and move Row-wise or Column-wise.
two_pointer_techniques.key_insight: Utilizes 2D sorting to eliminate an entire row or column in every single step, reducing search complexity.
common_applications: Search in a 2D Sorted Matrix II

two_pointer_techniques.name: Binary Search (Logarithmic Pointers)
two_pointer_techniques.movement: Pointers jump to the midpoint of the range rather than incrementing by 1.
two_pointer_techniques.key_insight: Reduces the search space by half in each iteration by evaluating the relationship between bounds.

two_pointer_techniques.name: Interval Pointers (Sweep Line)
two_pointer_techniques.movement: One pointer iterates through sorted start times, and another through sorted end times.
two_pointer_techniques.key_insight: Allows tracking of concurrent events or overlaps by treating intervals as discrete events.

two_pointer_techniques.name: Triple Pointers (Partitioning)
two_pointer_techniques.movement: Three pointers (Low, Mid, High) divide an array into three logical sections.
two_pointer_techniques.key_insight: Enables sorting of three distinct categories/values in a single pass (3-way partitioning).

two_pointer_techniques.name: Cyclic Pointers (Index as Pointer)
two_pointer_techniques.movement: The value at the current pointer's index is used as the address for the next pointer location.
two_pointer_techniques.key_insight: Treats array values as pointers to detect duplicates or missing numbers within a fixed range [1, n].

two_pointer_techniques.name: Two-Pass Greedy Pointers
two_pointer_techniques.movement: One pointer pass from Left-to-Right, followed by a separate pointer pass from Right-to-Left.
two_pointer_techniques.key_insight: Builds prefix and suffix constraints independently to solve problems where an element depends on both neighbors.
